advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRO7 COVERPAGE (SEPT. 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Micro7 was a french computing magazine in the 80's. In september 84, its first page was featuring the EXl-100.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DESKTOP & PORTABLE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Alice, a computer for all levels"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said : <br><br> ''The computer which carried away America"<br><br> ''With its portable computers, Compaq became world number two on the market of the 16 bits computers. With a turnover of 240 million dollars in one year and a half, this young company established in Houston obtained the growth rate record of the American economic history." </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The major argument of the advert campaign was "we have a better and cheaper computer than Apple and IBM"...<br><br> True, but like many other computers of the time, the major fault of the Advantage was not to be an IBM system...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - JAN.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT FROM NEW ZEALAND</strong></font><br><blockquote>In November 1976, the assembled basic version cost A$931, the unassembled version cost A$599.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BAKED APPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Olivetti M10, the portable professional micro-computer, here comes why."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SUPERBRAIN II ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>SuperBrain II's internal circuitry has been completely redesigned. There were four models availables, from 350 KB to 10 MB of storage capacity.<br><br> The new version offered a faster enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes ans better graphics capabilities. <br><br> Prices started at $2,495</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>...released in "l'Ordinateur Individuel" magazine n°12<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Fabien Neck and its <a href="http://www.system-cfg.com/" target="_blank">website</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Kyotronics 85 may be considered the world's first true laptop computer.
It was designed and sold in Japan by Kyocera (Kyoto Ceramics). But curiously, apart from the Japanese market, it was little sold in the world despite its very innovative design.
On the other hand, three major computer firms noticed this little gem and licenced it. Shortly afterwards, one would see the same computer sold under three different names and case designs in every corner of the world. These machines were the NEC PC-8201, the Tandy Model 100 and the Olivetti M10.
Each brand added its own enhancement - arrow keys for the NEC, tilt display for the Olivetti, but the hardware basis was identical: an 8085 CPU, 8 to 32 KB of RAM, a full-size typewriter keyboard and an 8-line x 40-character LCD display.
Later, Tandy asked Kyocera to introduce changes and released the Tandy 102 (larger memory) then the Tandy 200 (larger display).
computer.keyboard: Typewriter type, 72 keys with 16 function keys and 4 arrow keys
computer.name: Kyotronic 85
computer.ports: Parallel printer, Tape recorder, Bar Code reader, Serial RS232, Phone, System bus
computer.power: 6V DC adaptor or 4 x AA batteries
